title: Radical Rigs: Blake Hansen’s Lexus 1996 FZJ80 and Specialized Status – Paul Kalifatidi
content:
People ride bikes for many reasons: their practicality, simplicity, exercise, and, hell, even for fun. Adding aftermarket details, tuning the bike to their preferences, and making aesthetic choices are all part of the joy of self-expression through these mechanical contraptions. Bikes can be a labor of love.

Many bike tinkerers possess an overlapping interest in vehicles. For many of us, cars, trucks, vans, and four-wheeled contraptions are just larger and more complicated sources of labor and recipients of love than our bikes. Few bike repairs involve laying on freezing concrete and sending a tight fist filled with a cold ratchet at Mach 3 into the bottom of a steering rack.

Most bikes can be repaired without an obscure connection to an overseas junkyard. For those of us who appreciate unreliability and tom-foolery, we present Radical Rigs, with support from 1Up USA. Like the bikes on The Radavist, these rigs might be perfect. They also might be so far from perfection that they go full circle and become better than perfect. They might be dented and dinged, they might be muddy and marred, but they’re all rad.

For this installment of this series, Paul Kalifatidi presents a portrait of free-rider, Blake Hansen, and her 80-series Land Cruiser and bar-spinning Specialized Status.

Blake and I don’t remember how we met. It might have been at Hangtime, a women-focused free-ride event in town that I’ve photographed. It might have been one of many dinners we have here in Bellingham to stave off winter’s darkness and dampness. It might have been when I photographed her for some new jorts. I later photographed her for a SRAM GX launch.

Paul photographed Black for a SRAM GX Transmission launch in 2024…

Regardless, I think the initial idea for this series was subconsciously born when I said that I loved her Land Cruiser and she said that it had never been in a photo shoot. So, finally, at last, we can let Blake’s FZJ80 Lecus LX have its moment. Here is the cruiser in all of its patina glory.

Toyota or Lexus?

For those who don’t know, Lexus is Toyota’s luxury brand. There are many theories about the name. Is it a combination of “luxury and elegance?” Is it a contraction of “luxury export to the US?” The brand has never explicitly stated where the name comes from besides the fact that it gives off a vibe of technological capability and luxurious refinement.

The 80-series Land Cruiser is one of the most coveted SUVs. It is the last US-market Toyota with a solid front axle and has full-time four-wheel drive, i.e., you’re always driving in 4-high but can shift into 4-low via the transfer case. In offroading, maintaining contact with the ground for traction and stability is everything. A solid axle pushes one wheel down while the wheel on the opposite side is pushed up, forcing the wheels into the undulations of the terrain.

After the 80 series, all Toyota trucks have used independent front suspension, which provides superior on-road handling and suspension performance at higher speeds but isn’t as traction-hungry in slower, rockier situations.

The 80 series is still perfectly capable of regular vehicle duties, which is part of the reason it is such a desirable vehicle. Even the nicest 80 series is pushing 30 years old, so well-maintained specimens command a hefty price and frequently sell for the same price as a modern SUV, and sometimes more.

Toyota initially released the 80 series in 1990 as the FJ80. It had the 3F-E engine, which was reliable yet considered underpowered for the size of its mated vehicle. In 1992, Toyota added the more powerful 1FZ-FE as an additional engine option and a few other upgrades like rear disc brakes instead of the FZ’s drum brakes (see: better).

For the last two years of the model run (1996-1997), these trucks were also sold under the Lexus brand as LX450, a hilariously blatant rebadge of the Toyota product. The only differences were Lexus badging, a leather interior, and paint only available to the luxury model. It would take a second generation of the Lexus LX to start to look a little different.

The 100 series rebadge at least featured different headlights. To this day, Lexus and Toyota still have essentially identical vehicles with slightly different fascia, especially when you look at what is available in overseas markets.

Blake’s 80 has the coveted full-floating rear axle with special Lexus-issued chrome wheels

My favorite features of the 80-series Land Cruiser are the sliding rear windows, two-piece tailgate (truck stuff), and a full-floating rear axle. This means if you ever break your axle studs, your wheels won’t fall off like a semi-float axle. It’s also stronger, easier to service, and, unlike the earlier 80 Series releases, has disc brakes. These are the most apparent features that my Land Cruiser Prado doesn’t have. In a later post, we’ll feature my own vehicle.

Previous to the Land Cruiser, Blake had several Toyotas, including a Toyota Pickup that a neighbor routinely tried to buy from her and a 2nd generation 4Runner. For most Toyota people, Land Cruisers are the end-all acquisition. For Blake, it was no different. She found this one in the driveway of a friend’s neighbor. Eventually, it had a for-sale sign on it. The right truck for the right price was too good to pass up.

Onto the Bike: Specialized STATUS 2 140

Blake is a professional free-rider for Specialized. She was recently invited to shadow the judging process at Redbull Rampage, the first to feature female riders. Her STATUS 2 140 reflects those sendy tendencies. It’s burly, it’s capable, and it’s made of Metal. It’s built with some of her signature colorway components from Bellingham’s Tenet Components. How many trail bikes do you see rolling around town with brake hoses routed through the steerer tube for bar spins?

The Status is an interesting bike, perhaps because of its oddly covert marketing strategy rather than its features. It was first revealed on professional riders’ social media when it came out. Even after it was available from select bike shops, it was easiest to find information about it from some grom at the local pump track. The goal was to drive interest among the young, gravity-focused crowd with an alluring and exclusive feeling marketing strategy.

Paul photographed Black for a SRAM GX Transmission launch in 2024…

Unlike exclusive bikes, it is affordable. A few years later, it is now in its second iteration: a simple and capable rig at a stellar value. Much like the analog and gimmick-free vehicles I love, it is a refreshingly bare-bones offering in Specialized’s engineering and acronym-heavy catalog.

For those who might be Cruiser curious, Blake’s 450 is for sale. It recently received a new head gasket, cylinder head resurface, heater hoses, spark plugs, ignition wiring, and other maintenance items that will keep it rolling for another 200,000 miles.  It also has very rare chrome rims, coveted by Cruiser heads! Make her an offer. Maybe you’ll own this Radical Rig.

1996 Lexus LX450

  • Model code: J80
  • 4.5 L 1FZ-FE motor (inline-six cylinder, twin-cam, 24 valves)
  • 160 kW (215 hp) and 373 N⋅m (275 lb⋅ft) of torque.
  • 4-speed automatic transmission
  • Full-float rear axle
  • Full-time four-wheel drive with selectable locking center differential and low gearing
  • Four-wheel disc brakes
  • Solid axles front and rear
  • Years Produced: 1996-1997
  • Wheelbase: 2,850 mm (112.2 in)
  • Length: 4,821 mm (189.8 in)
  • Width: 1,930 mm (76.0 in)
  • Height: 1,869 mm (73.6 in)
  • Curb weight: 2,100 kg (4,760 lb)

Specialized STATUS 2 140

  • 140 mm travel frame and fork
  • Flip chip for modifying geometry
  • 30 or 38 mm BB drop
  • 77.6º or 77º effective seat tube angle
  • 64º or 64.5º Head Tube Angle (flip chip)
  • Geometry that splits the difference between the trail bike and enduro bike categories.
